markdownRemark.html:
Using Git locally

Ever wanted to use git version control without using github, and running it on your own computer?

This post is a collection of commands to get started with a locally hosted repo that you can use for local development without having to upload to any server.

Obviously you’re not safe from hardware failure and you are missing lot’s of github specific features including collaboration (a biggie!), but being closer to the terminal and a self-hosted git solution can be fun for working on toy projects.

A git workflow for using a local file store as your master

Why use git locally?

It works completely offline and can be used to practice git commands and local development practices, without polluting your github account with loads of tiny repo’s with unpolished work in.

Think of it like a personal sandbox for you to make unlimited private repo’s to practice development and development with git. It’s just your computer + git.

Less mental overhead than managing a github account + repo’s if you’re only making toy projects for learning.

I’m using git locally with two directories:

  1. A directory called /Code which has projects in.
  2. A directory called /CodeBackups which has bare git repo’s of the projects.

Basic set up

Making your backup location

  • Use mkdir CodeBackups or whatever you want to call it to make a new folder
  • Make a new a project directory CodeBackups/projectName
  • cd into the project in the CodeBackups directory.
  • run the command git init --bare

This creates a github-like repo with no checked-out branches, this way you can push to any branch in the repo including master.

Development

  • In your existing codebase in somewhere like code/projectname rungit init` to make a new repo
  • use git remote add origin ~/CodeBackups/projectName
  • add and commit your changes then run git push to push your code to the codeBackups/projectName repo.

You can now do stuff like delete your working directory and clone from the CodeBackups repo to carry on working at any time, and use git how you would normally sue it, but with a local repo.

What was the point of this again?

Running your own local git repo shows you what is happening behind the scenes, a repo made with git init --bare is what each of your github repo’s are, and is how people did stuff before github.

Most (new)developers only ever use github and never use git on it’s own so at least for me I always wanted to understand the mental models of git before hooking into github.
